item.title: about the website
item.description: To build this website I use several open-source software/plugins. Each one represent a step of my workflow: Zotero and Better BibTex to reference, annotate documents locally.

item.title: Anfinsen's dogma
item.description: It is an postulate for the protein folding problem. The native structure of proteins in the physiological environement is solely determined by the amino acid sequence.

item.title: molecular chaperon
item.description: They aid proteins to fold by restricting conformations. They are driving forces, such as the solvent.

item.title: prion
item.description: The word comes from “proteinaceous infectious particle”. Prions are misfolded proteins that have the ability to transmit their misfolded shape onto normal variants of the same protein.

item.title: protein folding problem
item.description: How does a protein folds ? Levinthal’s paradox states that if the protein tries all configurations, it will take forever. However, it does fold.

item.title: automaton
item.description: Formally, a finite automaton can be defined as $$\begin{array}{l}\text { A finite automaton (or machine) is a } 5 \text {-tuple } M=\left(Q, \Sigma, \delta, q_{0}, F\right) \text {, where } \ \text { 1.

item.title: Brillouin's relation between entropy and information
item.description: In 1951, Brilliouin related information and entropy to resolve Maxwell’s demon paradox; more precisely Shannon’s theory of information transmission and the second principle of thermodynamics.

item.title: computability
item.description: Three notions of computability are equivalent: The existence of a Turing machine computing the function. The abacus-computability. A recursive function A function is computable on a Turing machine if and only if it is a recursive function

item.title: Crick's central dogma
item.description: It postulates that proteins never transmit “sequential information”. “Sequential information” is to be understood as the sequence of bases in DNA or amino-acids in proteins.

item.title: deterministic system
item.description: A system is deterministic when it has a conceivable determination in explicit mathematics. It does not require the maths to be solvable in practice.

item.title: entropy
item.description: For a given phase space, Hamiltonian and energy, entropy quantifies the number of micro-states available. Details In the Gibbs (canonical) ensemble (NVT), the partition function reads $$ Z = \sum_i e^{-\beta E_i} $$an with the probability of the micro-state $i$ being $p_i=e^{-\beta E_i} / Z$, we have $$ S_G=-k_B \sum_i p_i \log(p_i) $$

item.title: Laplacian determinism
item.description: A demiurge could predict the future with solely position and velocity of all particles in the universe. Laplace states that any deterministic system is therefore predictable.

item.title: literature note on Longo2012
item.description: Is Information a proper observable for biological organization? by Longo G., Miquel P., Sonnenschein C., Soto A.M. (2012) Progress in biophysics and molecular biology 109: 108-114 DOI: 10.

item.title: Maxwell's demon paradox
item.description: It was suggested in 1867 by Maxwell. A ‘finite being’ can open or close a door between two boxes. Depending on the velocity of the particle that is coming close to the door, he lets fast particles go to one side and slow ones on the other side.

item.title: Mendelian inheritance
item.description: In 1865, the monk and botanist Gregor Mendel find that a trait can different forms (alleles) and suggested three laws:

item.title: negentropy
item.description: First mentionned in Schrodinger1944 to characterize living systems, it is rigourously introduced by Brillouin1951 to relate it to the opposite of entropy and positively to information (see Brillouin’s relation between entropy and information).

item.title: Schrödinger's code-script aperiodic crystal
item.description: In 1944, Schrödinger imagine that a “code-script” could be found in “aperiodic crystals” (chromosomes) of living systems ( Schrodinger1944). Without mentionning “information”, it does refer to a discrete encoding and therefore implies Laplacian determinism (and predictability).

item.title: second principe of thermodynamic
item.description: The entropy of a closed system with fixed volume can only increase. It is maximum at equilibrium for a system at constant energy.

item.title: Shannon's theory of information transmission
item.description: Be $X$ a random variable with $X\in{x_1,x_2,…,x_n}$ and $p_i=\mathbb{P}(X=x_i)$. Shannon relates the amount of information of one string to the amount of surprise of seeing it.

item.title: Turing machine
item.description: In 1936, Turing introduces the idea of a “computing machine”, latter called “Turing machine”. He pictures not a mecanism but a person — “Turing’s architect” according to ( Schrodinger1944) Turing introduced ( Turing1936) this machine trying to answer questions regarding decidability.

item.title: abacus
item.description: An abacus is a “higher-level” (more flexible) Turing machine for computation. Every abacus-computable function is Turing computable. All recursive functions are abacus-computable.

item.title: arithmetic function
item.description: A function whose domain is $\mathbb{N}$.

item.title: Cantor's diagonal argument
item.description: One of Cantor’s theorem is that the set of all sets of natural numbers is not enumerable. The set of real numbers is the set of all set of natural numbers because you form a real number by precising its decimals.

item.title: Church-Turing thesis
item.description: An arithmetic function is effectively computable if and only if it is computable (see computability). This is a thesis because it is not provable because it refers to the informal effectively computable notion.

item.title: effectively computable
item.description: This informal notion also refers to: procedure paper-and-pencil method or to a mechanical method It is specific to a type of problem but we can state:

item.title: enumerable set
item.description: A set is enumerable if and only if it is the range of some arithmetic function. (The range is the set of the function’s values.

item.title: halting problem
item.description: Given a Turing machine and an initial binary strings, the problem consists in knowing if it will halt or not. This problem cannot be solve on a Turing machine because the halting function is uncomputable.

item.title: recursive function
item.description: It refers to functions that can be built with the zero, the successor and the identity function by use of composition, minimization and primitive recursion: $$h(x,0)=f(x), \ h(x,y’)=g(x,y,h(x,y))$$ They are all effectively computable.

item.title: uncomputable
item.description: Due to Cantor’s diagonal argument, we know that the set of arithmetic functions that have a range on positive integers is not an enumerable set.

item.title: Where am I?
item.description: Welcome! You are on my personal website. You can find out about me by clicking on the (colored) bold link.

Poincaré showed that the three-body problem (gravitation) cannot be analytically solved. Non-observable continuous fluctuations (below any physical instrument precision) can be amplified non-linearly.

item.title: about me
item.description: Hello, I’m Anton Robert. I am a physical chemist, highly interested in theoretical biology. Take a look at my manifesto to understand why.

item.title: Boolos2007
item.description: Computability and Logic by Boolos G.S., Burgess J.P., Jeffrey R.C. (2007) Cambridge University Press Abstract: Computability and Logic has become a classic because of its accessibility to students without a mathematical background and because it covers not simply the staple topics of an intermediate logic course, such as Godel’s incompleteness theorems, but also a large number of optional topics, from Turing’s theory of computability to Ramsey’s theorem.
